componentAttributes.richTextValue:
Salesforce Developer (Contract)

Nov 2019 - Current



Application Support Analyst (Contract)

Sept 2018 – Oct 2019


One week after earning my Salesforce Admin certification, I was grateful to land a job with Johnson & Johnson as an Application Support Analyst. Technology Services at J&J can be split up into two sectors: BUILD and RUN. This role was within the RUN sector. Furthermore, the RUN sector can be split up even further into various clusters with varying technology specialties. The cluster I served on was called Customer & Sales which specializes primarily in Salesforce technology. The application portfolio boasts over 30 unique Salesforce instances. Each of these Salesforce applications are owned by a Johnson and Johnson business, and the day-to-day support activities that may be required for these applications are done by a 3rd-party vendor (Cognizant for Customer & Sales). Thus, the RUN team serves as a liaison between the owning-business and the vendor.


Since these support activites are done by contractors, I seldomly found myself within a Salesforce instance doing actual support. However, I often did help triage incident tickets submitted by varios application users through an internal ticketing tool developed by J&J called IRIS. Thus, my understanding of Salesforce is being applied and growing every day to help mitigate issues.

While that broadly covers some of the day-to-day duties, I was also responsible for several long-term projects and goals:


  • Operations Run Book (ORB): Key documentation for an application includes a Technical Design Specifications (TDS) and an Operations Run Book (ORB). A TDS is created by the BUILD team during development, and details the entire inner workings and acrchitecture of an application. An ORB further details information that may not be covered by a TDS such as points of failures, impacted user communities, communication and resolution protocols for outages, and comprehensive contact information. When I came onto the team and started learning about supporting the cluster's applications, I was pointed towards the application's corresponding ORB to learn more about supporting any said application. However, we soon realized the overall landscape of our cluster's ORBs was in a poor state. Thus, I was put in charge of an effort to work with the various support teams to help improve the quality of each application's ORB and bring them to our baseline standards.


  • Aggrify: One of my favorite projects was enabling a service-level targeting tool offered by another RUN team cluster (Data & Analytics) called Aggrify. This tool captures pertinent metadata about any jobs a application may have. We enabled this tool specifically for Scheduled Apex classes within our various Salesforce applications. With Aggrify enabled, we could monitor for job success and failures, analyze the mean time for a job to complete, and troubleshoot possible solutions to make the job run more efficiently.


  • Knowledge Articles: Whenever a incident ticket is resolved in IRIS, you are required to find or create an appropriate Knowledge Article that details the steps taken to resolve the issue in order to close the ticket. Over-time you build a strong Knowledge Base, and steps to resolve repeated issues can be found easily. However, over-time we have found that the vendor had cut corners, and created lazy Knowledge Articles that have no sustenance whatsoever, and only polluted the Knowledge Base. To help mitigate this issue, our cluster created an audit process to randomly select various Knowledge Articles created in the prior month and verify the quality of their content. If a Knowledge Article does not meet the baseline standards, we provided feedback to the original author and they were to update it appropriately.


  • CopyStorm: CopyStorm is a suite of 3rd party tools offered by CapStorm which allow you to backup salesforce data and metadata, and restore it to any environment. So, should an application have a major release go awry, you can restore a production environment to a previous stable state with clean data. We have started integrating our portfolio of applications with CopyStorm since mid 2019. While this service is primarily supported by our vendor (Cognizant), a co-worker and I have been involved in the process as an learning experience.

Intern Junior Developer

Jun 2015 – Aug 2018


While attending college at University of South Florida Sarasota-Manatee, I was fortunate enough to intern part-time as a Junior Developer at Franco Signor LLC. The company operates within the Medicare industry; more specifically Medicare Secondary Payer (MSP) compliance and solutions. As a Junior Developer, my day-to-day responsibilities included:


  • Programming SSIS packages that query client data using SQL which is then transformed and imported into the appropriate Salesforce objects.
  • Design and develop various internal, web-based applications (.NET/C#) that allow the sales and operations teams to interact with client data.
  • Collaborate in a team environment with IT, operations, and sales to design and create customized solutions crucial to business operations.
  • Maintain existing applications to eliminate bugs, add minor enhancements, and improve business productivity.
  • Develop customized SSRS reports for analysis based on business requirements.
  • Database design, maintenance, and normalization in SQL Server Management Studio
  • Provide maintenance and support for company’s public facing WordPress website: https://francosignor.com/
